MC	<p>e178_182e</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene K</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">70,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>K</b> and <b>W</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>K</b> and <b>W</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(1,455 + 1,515 + 21,339)</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = <sup>24,309</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = 0.3473 = <strong>34.73 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(5,446 + 5,465 + 6,612 + 6,756)</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = <sup>24,279</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = 0.3468 = <strong>34.68 cM</strong>	Correct	C. <sup>(5,465 + 6,612)</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = <sup>12,077</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = 0.1725 = <strong>17.25 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(21,339 + 21,412)</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = <sup>42,751</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = 0.6107 = <strong>61.07 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>5,446</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = <sup>5,446</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = 0.0778 = <strong>7.78 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>6,612</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = <sup>6,612</sup>/<sub>70,000</sub> = 0.0945 = <strong>9.45 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>400c_9d12</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene F</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene K</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, kidney, mushy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>faa4_669e</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene J</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>e2aa_697c</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene P</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>89d6_b3d8</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">mushy, nerdy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>11fa_a630</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene E</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene F</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">e</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ecffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">e</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #4d9900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">25,745</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, jerky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>ff33_545c</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene N</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">horsey, nerdy, xanthic</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>d052_bee2</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene E</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene P</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">60,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>E</b> and <b>W</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>E</b> and <b>W</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(961 + 10,886)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>11,847</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.1974 = <strong>19.74 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(961 + 1,043 + 7,682 + 10,580)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>20,266</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.3378 = <strong>33.78 cM</strong>	Incorrect	C. <sup>961</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>961</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.0160 = <strong>1.60 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(7,600 + 10,580)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>18,180</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.3030 = <strong>30.30 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(10,642 + 10,886)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>21,528</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.3588 = <strong>35.88 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(7,600 + 7,682 + 10,580 + 10,606)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>36,468</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.6078 = <strong>60.78 cM</strong>	Correct
MC	<p>7224_2b1b</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene A</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene B</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene K</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>a8ab_f461</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene C</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene F</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>cd32_6619</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene K</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>dac7_8c5c</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene P</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy, prickly, rusty</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>4514_c9a0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene H</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene N</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">h</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">nerdy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">n</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>d011_d94d</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>d6f7_4bc0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene M</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">140,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>D</b> and <b>M</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>D</b> and <b>M</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(925 + 42,382)</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = <sup>43,307</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = 0.3093 = <strong>30.93 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(3,236 + 3,395 + 23,194 + 23,323)</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = <sup>53,148</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = 0.3796 = <strong>37.96 cM</strong>	Correct	C. <sup>23,194</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = <sup>23,194</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = 0.1657 = <strong>16.57 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(42,382 + 42,645)</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = <sup>85,027</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = 0.6073 = <strong>60.73 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(900 + 23,194 + 23,323)</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = <sup>47,417</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = 0.3387 = <strong>33.87 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(3,236 + 42,382)</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = <sup>45,618</sup>/<sub>140,000</sub> = 0.3258 = <strong>32.58 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>3984_d7d4</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene H</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene R</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; MC	<p>5d46_658f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene C</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene N</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>124c_2406</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene P</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>5dd7_5d1d</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; MC	<p>6ab0_dba4</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene B</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy, bumpy, jerky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">a</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f5f7ee; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">26,047</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">a</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">4,710</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">bumpy, jerky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>c15e_9191</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene T</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">bumpy, tipsy, waxy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>e4c1_009a</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene J</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene W</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">40,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>J</b> and <b>W</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>J</b> and <b>W</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(114 + 131 + 1,638 + 1,685)</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = <sup>3,568</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = 0.0892 = <strong>8.92 cM</strong>	Correct	B. <sup>(1,638 + 1,685 + 3,963)</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = <sup>7,286</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = 0.1822 = <strong>18.21 cM</strong>	Incorrect	C. <sup>(14,208 + 14,245)</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = <sup>28,453</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = 0.7113 = <strong>71.13 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(114 + 131)</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = <sup>245</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = 0.0061 = <strong>0.61 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(114 + 131 + 1,638 + 1,685 + 3,963 + 4,016)</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = <sup>11,547</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = 0.2887 = <strong>28.87 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(4,016 + 14,208)</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = <sup>18,224</sup>/<sub>40,000</sub> = 0.4556 = <strong>45.56 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>eac7_b80e</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene B</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene J</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>23e1_760e</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene C</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene K</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>3b7b_4dfa</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene K</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>e8e0_8350</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy, tipsy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>2583_86d6</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene K</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene R</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">53,119</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #076cab;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #800055;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">29,768</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>9cd5_a8c6</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene F</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, nerdy, rusty</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>ebd0_fb0d</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene C</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene E</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">60,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>C</b> and <b>E</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>C</b> and <b>E</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(1,845 + 1,914 + 4,582 + 4,583)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>12,924</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.2154 = <strong>21.54 cM</strong>	Correct	B. <sup>4,583</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>4,583</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.0764 = <strong>7.64 cM</strong>	Incorrect	C. <sup>(13,677 + 13,890)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>27,567</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.4595 = <strong>45.95 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(1,845 + 1,914 + 4,582 + 4,583 + 13,890)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>26,814</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.4469 = <strong>44.69 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>1,845</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>1,845</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.0307 = <strong>3.08 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(1,845 + 1,914 + 4,582 + 9,868)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>18,209</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.3035 = <strong>30.35 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>6cf2_269c</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene H</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene K</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene P</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>e2bc_8aec</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>bc5e_9746</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene C</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene E</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene H</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; MC	<p>88d8_ab62</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #663300;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #663300;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #663300;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene T</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #004080;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #004080;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, tipsy, xanthic</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>24cf_93a0</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene H</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene T</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black;
