MC	<p>6967_1102</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene M</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene X</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy, mushy, xanthic</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>e472_dea6</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene C</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">110,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>C</b> and <b>W</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>C</b> and <b>W</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(1,053 + 19,830 + 25,596)</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = <sup>46,479</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = 0.4225 = <strong>42.25 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(1,053 + 1,126 + 8,388 + 8,463)</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = <sup>19,030</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = 0.1730 = <strong>17.30 cM</strong>	Correct	C. <sup>(1,126 + 19,830 + 25,596)</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = <sup>46,552</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = 0.4232 = <strong>42.32 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(1,053 + 8,388)</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = <sup>9,441</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = 0.0858 = <strong>8.58 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(25,577 + 25,596)</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = <sup>51,173</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = 0.4652 = <strong>46.52 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(8,463 + 25,596)</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = <sup>34,059</sup>/<sub>110,000</sub> = 0.3096 = <strong>30.96 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>3545_f558</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>artsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene A</span> has wings that are colorful and distinctive patterns.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene C</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">artsy, chummy, rusty</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>38d4_9de3</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene N</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>7f99_ff84</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; MC	<p>66bb_ddc6</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">eery, mushy, yucky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>75e8_a97c</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene F</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene T</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, prickly, tipsy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #fff9e5; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6fff3; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">30,030</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #fff9e5; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">prickly, tipsy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b37100;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>e150_7268</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>bumpy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene B</span> has a skin texture that is not smooth, but rough with small bumps all over.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene N</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">bumpy, fuzzy, nerdy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>6aae_1373</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene K</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>kidney</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene K</span> has a body shape that is curved, similar to a kidney bean.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">290,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>K</b> and <b>T</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>K</b> and <b>T</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(2,914 + 3,017 + 34,804 + 72,236)</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = <sup>112,971</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = 0.3896 = <strong>38.96 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(2,914 + 3,017 + 34,804 + 34,955)</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = <sup>75,690</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = 0.2610 = <strong>26.10 cM</strong>	Correct	C. <sup>(2,914 + 3,017 + 34,804 + 72,257)</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = <sup>112,992</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = 0.3896 = <strong>38.96 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(72,236 + 72,257)</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = <sup>144,493</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = 0.4983 = <strong>49.83 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(3,017 + 34,955 + 72,236)</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = <sup>110,208</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = 0.3800 = <strong>38.00 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(2,914 + 3,017 + 35,049)</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = <sup>40,980</sup>/<sub>290,000</sub> = 0.1413 = <strong>14.13 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>ca1d_6d1a</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene H</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>8324_cdec</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene N</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>nerdy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene N</span> has large, prominent eyes that stand out, much like thick-rimmed glasses.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene P</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>6414_8a0e</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene J</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene P</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>d244_e158</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene H</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene P</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; MC	<p>efdb_f85d</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene J</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene M</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">jerky, mushy, rusty</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">j</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6ffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">j</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008080;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6ff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">r</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">15,823</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">jerky</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">j</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008080;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #99004d;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">4,118</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">mushy, rusty</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>d18e_1006</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene E</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene T</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">eery, tipsy, waxy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>cb5e_a550</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene H</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>dfa5_582c</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>chummy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene C</span> shows behavior where it always maintains a close distance to other flies.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>prickly</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene P</span> is covered with sharp bristles, giving it a spiky texture.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #690f8a;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #690f8a;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>d8c5_9a48</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene M</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene R</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; MC	<p>9fe3_37be</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene D</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #4d9900;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #4d9900;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene T</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>540b_8b02</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b34100;">Gene E</span></strong> is correlated with the '<span style="color: #b34100;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b34100;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene J</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene X</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>xanthic</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene X</span> has a fluorescent bright yellow coloring.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; MC	<p>57ac_2b6f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #999900;">Gene H</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #999900;"><i>horsey</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #999900;">Gene H</span> is quite big and strong-looking, much larger than your typical fruit fly.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #008066;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008066;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Genotypes</span></th><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, horsey, tipsy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffe6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #e6fff3; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">t</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">35,105</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffe6e6; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #000000;">f</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #999900;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #008066;">+</span></td><td align="right" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">1,817</span></td></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">horsey, tipsy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #f8f8f8; padding: 5px;"><span style="font-size: large; color: #b30000;">+</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>5687_185f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene F</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #076cab;"><i>jerky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #076cab;">Gene J</span> moves in rapid and sudden movements, displaying an unpredictable flight pattern.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; color: #000000;">Progeny<br/>Count</span></th></tr><tr><td align="left" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #ffffff; padding: 5px;">&nbsp;<span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">fuzzy, jerky, waxy</span></td><td align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>48b5_56c8</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #465927;">Gene D</span></strong> is analogous to the '<span style="color: #465927;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #465927;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span></strong> is associated with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>waxy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene W</span> has a thick protective layer that is water resistant and opague.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span></strong> is connected with the '<span style="color: #800055;"><i>yucky</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #800055;">Gene Y</span> gives off an unpleasant odor and has a generally unappealing look.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">60,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>D</b> and <b>Y</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>D</b> and <b>Y</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>9,370</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>9,370</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.1562 = <strong>15.62 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(1,580 + 1,586)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>3,166</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.0528 = <strong>5.28 cM</strong>	Incorrect	C. <sup>9,288</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>9,288</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.1548 = <strong>15.48 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>(18,640 + 18,712)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>37,352</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.6225 = <strong>62.25 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(400 + 424 + 1,580 + 1,586)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>3,990</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.0665 = <strong>6.65 cM</strong>	Correct	F. <sup>(400 + 424 + 1,580 + 18,640)</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = <sup>21,044</sup>/<sub>60,000</sub> = 0.3507 = <strong>35.07 cM</strong>	Incorrect
MC	<p>3af1_007f</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span></strong> is affiliated with the '<span style="color: #b30000;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b30000;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #008000;"><i>rusty</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008000;">Gene R</span> has a reddish-brown color, much like rusted iron metal.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene T</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>9622_b06e</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>dewy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene D</span> appears moist, with its body covered in tiny droplets of water.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #002db3;">Gene M</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #002db3;"><i>mushy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #002db3;">Gene M</span> feels soft to the touch and unusually squishy, unlike the usual firmness.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; border: 2px solid black;"><tr><th align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; background-color: #cccccc; padding: 10px;"><span style="font-size: medium; color: #000000;">Phenotype</span></th><th colspan="3" align="center" style="border: 1px solid black; MC	<p>4614_b1bb</p> <h4>Three-Point Test Cross Problem</h4><p>A test cross is a way to explore the relationship between genes and their respective alleles. It is a useful tool for genetic mapping and deciphering the inheritance of traits. Specifically, a three-point test cross examines three (3) genes at the same time to learn about their assortment in gamete formation.</p><p>A standard three-point test cross involves crossing a heterozygous organism for all three genes with an organism that is homozygous recessive for all three genes</p> <p>For this problem, a test cross using a fruit fly (<i>Drosophila melanogaster</i>) heterozygous for three genes was conducted to understand their genetic interactions.</p><h6>Characteristics of Recessive Phenotypes</h6><p><ul><li><strong><span style="color: #b37100;">Gene E</span></strong> is related to the '<span style="color: #b37100;"><i>eery</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #b37100;">Gene E</span> appears to have something off, crooked limbs and other twisted appendages.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #008080;">Gene F</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #008080;"><i>fuzzy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #008080;">Gene F</span> is covered in a dense layer of hairs, giving it a soft appearance.</li> <li><strong><span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span></strong> is linked with the '<span style="color: #99004d;"><i>tipsy</i></span>' phenotype. A fruit fly that is homozygous recessive for <span style="color: #99004d;">Gene T</span> moves in an erratic path, suggesting a lack of coordination, as if intoxicated.</li> </ul></p><table style="border-collapse: collapse; color: #000000;">75,000</span></td></tr></table><p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <p>The resulting phenotypes are summarized in the table above.</p> <h6>Question</h6> <p>With the progeny data from the table, and using only the genotypes that result from crossover events between the two genes <b>E</b> and <b>F</b> during meiosis.</p> <p><strong>calculate the genetic distance between the two genes <b>E</b> and <b>F</b>,</strong> expressing your answer in centimorgans (cM)</p>	A. <sup>(2,677 + 7,639)</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = <sup>10,316</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = 0.1375 = <strong>13.75 cM</strong>	Incorrect	B. <sup>(2,677 + 2,850 + 7,639 + 7,819)</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = <sup>20,985</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = 0.2798 = <strong>27.98 cM</strong>	Correct	C. <sup>(2,677 + 2,850 + 7,639 + 9,532)</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = <sup>22,698</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = 0.3026 = <strong>30.26 cM</strong>	Incorrect	D. <sup>2,850</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = <sup>2,850</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = 0.0380 = <strong>3.80 cM</strong>	Incorrect	E. <sup>(2,850 + 9,631 + 17,174)</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = <sup>29,655</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = 0.3954 = <strong>39.54 cM</strong>	Incorrect	F. <sup>(17,174 + 17,678)</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = <sup>34,852</sup>/<sub>75,000</sub> = 0.4647 = <strong>46.47 cM</strong>	Incorrect
